docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration recently approved a new use for biosynthesized human growth hormone: treating unusually short children who don't have any other known disorder. In clinical studies, the drug, which is called Humatrope and made by Eli Lilly & Company, added several inches to kids' eventual height without producing any significant health risks. Humatrope, in other words, met the regulatory tests for safety and efficacy. But bioethicists greeted the decision with protests. ''We will start to treat the normal as a disease,'' Arthur Caplan of the University of Pennsylvania told The Washington Post, adding that ''whenever you take people on the low end of a distribution curve and say they have a disorder, you're starting down a slippery slope.''

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 8-31-03: ESSAY

docs.abstract: Virginia Postrel essay on trend of treating biological traits--shortness, myopia, disfiguring birthmarks--as diseases, and using medicine to counteract them; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Graham Skips The Quiet Car SENATOR BOB GRAHAM may have learned the value of discretion as a former chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee. But as a presidential candidate, he was hardly discreet, or quiet, as a passenger on Amtrak traveling to New York from Washington not long ago.

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal and local officials are growing increasingly concerned that nearly 60 percent of families who lost relatives in the September 2001 terror attacks have not filed claims with the victim compensation fund established by Congress. The most recent statistics show that 3,016 people died in the attacks at the World Trade Center and the Pentagon and aboard an airliner that crashed in Pennsylvania. But as of Friday, with the Dec. 22 deadline for applications less than four months away, only 1,240 death claims had been filed with the fund. And while no one knows exactly how many people were injured in the attacks, so far only 1,035 of them have sought compensation from the fund, which has no cap.

headline.main: CONCERN GROWING AS FAMILIES BYPASS 9/11 VICTIMS' FUND

docs.abstract: Federal and local officials are growing increasingly concerned that nearly 60 percent of families who lost relatives in Sept 2001 terror attacks have not filed claims with victim compensation fund with less than months to go before deadline; most recent statistics show that 3,016 people died in attacks at World Trade Center and Pentagon and aboard airliner that crashed in Pennsylvania, but only 1,240 death claims had been filed with fund; Kenneth R Feinberg, federally appointed lawyer who oversees fund and makes its final decisions, comments; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE idea is to emit irresistible hook-up potential in less than three minutes. No dinner. No movie. Just 180 seconds of extreme dating, sort of like how it's done in some parts of the animal world. Ricky Quiricone, a hunky physical education teacher from Westport, was trying his best to impress at each of the eight tables set up for breakneck bonding at Humphrey's East restaurant in Orange. In particular, he seemed to enjoy telling his extremely abridged life story to Karen Leach, an attractive Branford entrepreneur with long, blond hair. Within seconds, there was a connection, but not the kind either had in mind. When Mr. Quiricone, 23, told Ms. Leach, 42, his age, she said, ''I'm old enough to have breast-fed you.''

headline.main: I've Got a Date at 7, but I'll Work You in at 7:03

docs.abstract: Article desribes scene at Humphrey's East restaurant in Orange, Conn, as singles play type of musical-chairs dating game called speed dating; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mary Louise Sudders is to be married today to Bradley Frederick Richardson. Daniel Forte, a notary public of Kennebunkport, Me., will perform the civil ceremony on the beach at the home of the bridegroom's family on Drakes Island in Wells, Me. Ms. Sudders, 49, who is known as Marylou, is the president and chief executive officer of the Massachusetts Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, a private, nonprofit child welfare agency in Boston. She serves on the board of directors of the Massachusetts Association for Mental Health and from 1996 to 2003 was Commissioner of Mental Health for Massachusetts, both in Boston. She is the daughter of the late Lillian Beaumont Sudders of Goshen, N.Y., and the late Harry Ellsworth Sudders of Ballstone Lake, N.Y. Her father was an electrical engineer in Ballstone Lake. Her mother was a legal secretary at Patrick J. Boyle & Associates, a Goshen law firm.

docs.lead_paragraph: This fall marks a pivotal moment for Suffolk County, currently ridden by scandals over land purchases and health insurance and saddled with a budget gap in excess of $100 million. The county executive elected to succeed the three-term incumbent, Robert Gaffney, will have to deal with all those problems, and restore confidence in the much-abused program to preserve the county's fast-disappearing open spaces while pushing ahead with smart development to create jobs and affordable housing. Then there is the rising problem of ethnic tension, with Hispanic migrant workers the targets of beatings and arson. Voters in the Sept. 9 Democratic primary have a clear choice between William Cunningham and Steve Levy. The next county executive needs substantial executive experience, and on that count Mr. Cunningham, of Bay Shore, is the superior candidate. After a career as a federal prosecutor and a managing partner at a Long Island law firm, Mr. Cunningham was most recently chief deputy to the Nassau county executive, Thomas Suozzi. There, he helped usher in a still-unfolding but spectacular return to fiscal integrity.
docs.abstract: Editorial endorses William Cunningham in Democratic primary for county executive in Suffolk County, NY

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors and hospitals across the country are scrambling to satisfy the booming demand for surgery that shrinks the stomachs of severely obese people. Dozens of hospitals are adding special operating suites for the procedure, called bariatric surgery, which attracted wide notice after public figures like Al Roker of ''Today'' on NBC, Sharon Osbourne of ''The Osbournes'' on MTV and Representative Jerrold Nadler, a Manhattan Democrat, had it done. Some bariatric surgeons are fully scheduled 12 months in advance, and hundreds of doctors have jumped into the field recently and started to advertise their availability.

headline.main: Hospitals Pressured By Soaring Demand For Obesity Surgery

docs.abstract: Doctors and hospitals across country scramble to satisfy booming demand for surgery that shrinks stomachs of severely obese people; dozens of hospitals are adding special operating suites for procedure, called bariatric surgery, and some bariatric surgeons are fully scheduled 12 months in advance; hundreds of doctors are jumping into field and starting to advertise their availability; surgery attracted wide notice after public figures like Al Roker, Sharon Osbourne and Rep Jerrold Nadler had it done; bariatric procedures surged more than 40 percent last year, to 80,000, and are expected to climb to 120,000 this year; spending on bariatrics is approaching $3 billion a year, at average cost of $25,000 for each procedure; costs are major concern for insurance companies and employer health plans; surgeons say some insurers routinely delay approvals; doctors and patients are putting pressure on insurers to lower body-size threshold for paying for operation for people with weight-related diseases; photos (M)
